markdownRemark.html:
Creating a CI/CD pipeline requires understanding of different technologies like GIT, Docker, YAML and Containers. This post will show you how you can set up an CI/CD pipeline using bitbucket and GCP. After reading this blog, you should be able to set your pipeline within an hour.

Pre-requisites

  • Google Cloud Platform Account
  • Bitbucket Account
  • Code Editor
  • knowledge of Command Line

Step 1: Create Service Account and Assign Proper Roles

Create a Service account, assign role of Storage Admin, Object Admin and Object Creator to the service account, this will give write access to google container registry.

  1. Using Command Line

    • Make sure you have google cloud sdk installed on your machine. If not, you use this link for installation instruction on Linux, Windows

    • After installing sdk authorize yourself using following commands

      • gcloud init
      • gcloud auth login

    • Once you are authorized, make sure you are working on correct project and using proper zone

      • gcloud config list project

    • Create two variables in bash

      • export PROJECT_ID=GCP_PROJECT_ID

        Ex: export PROJECT_ID=production-project-123

      • export ACCOUNT=bitbucket-pipelines

        Ex: export ACCOUNT=bitbucket-pipelines

    • Create Service Account using command

      • gcloud -q iam service-accounts create ${ACCOUNT} --display-name ${ACCOUNT}

    • Assign Roles to Service Account you have just created

      • gcloud -q projects add-iam-policy-binding ${PROJECT_ID} <br>--member=serviceAccount:${ACCOUNT}@${PROJECT_ID}.iam.gserviceaccount.com --role roles/storage.admin
      • gcloud -q projects add-iam-policy-binding ${PROJECT_ID} --member=serviceAccount:${ACCOUNT}@${PROJECT_ID}.iam.gserviceaccount.com --role roles/storage.objectAdmin
      • gcloud -q projects add-iam-policy-binding ${PROJECT_ID} --member=serviceAccount:${ACCOUNT}@${PROJECT_ID}.iam.gserviceaccount.com --role roles/storage.objectCreator

    • Create key file for the service account using this command 

      • gcloud iam service-accounts keys create ~/key.json \  --iam-account serviceAccount:${ACCOUNT}@${PROJECT_ID}.iam.gserviceaccount.com
      • The above command will create a key file which will provide access to container registry and google cloud storage bucket. Make sure keep this file safe.
  2. Using google cloud platform UI

This link it will redirect you to service account creation page.

  • Click Select a project, choose your project, and click Open.
  • Click Create Service Account.
  • Enter a service account name (friendly display name), an optional description, select a role you wish to grant to the service account, and then click Save.
  • Create a key file with JSON type, make sure to keep this file as it gives access to google container repository

Step 2) Create Base64 Encoded Text File

Create a base64 encoding of service account created in step1. Using the following command.

  • For linux, use this command to create base 64 encoding file from json key file.

    base64 key.json > encoded.txt.

    This will save the encoded text in encoded.txt file

  • For windows, refer to this link

Step 3) Add service account credentials to bitbucket.

Login to bitbucket. Click on left bottom corner -> go to settings -> go to account variables

  • Add key as GCLOUD_API_KEYFILE. For Ex: GCLOUD_API_KEYFILE with value as encoded text stored in encoded.txt file.
  • Add another key as GCLOUD_PROJECT_ID. For Ex: GCLOUD_PROJECT_ID with value as ID of gcp project that will be used for deployment.
